Element RM Fe 23.32 O 42.78 Al 10.39 Si 4.73 Na 6.18 Ca 4.03 Ti 4.25 Slurry-phase hydrocracking of vacuum residue with a disposable red mud catalyst Chinh Nguyen-Huy a Hyukmin Kweon a Hanna Kim a Do Kyoung Kim b Do-Woan Kim b Seung Hoon Oh b Eun Woo Shin a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering, University of Ulsan, Daehakro 93, Nam-gu, Ulsan 680-749, South Korea b Catalyst Lab, SK Innovation, Exporo 325, Yuseong-gu, Daejon 305-712, South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 52 259 2253; fax: +82 52 259 1689. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Red mud was used as a catalyst in slurry-phase hydrocracking of vacuum residue. ► The conversion of feedstock to distillate was thermally controlled. ► Coke formation and cracking reaction were suppressed in the presence of catalyst. ► Pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ) was formed during reaction due to presence of sulfur in feed. ► Red mud was possibly self-activated during the reaction. In this study, red mud (RM) was used as a catalyst in slurry-phase hydrocracking of vacuum residue (VR) in batch system. Without RM, thermal cracking occurred and a lighter fraction and higher conversion was achieved than in the presence of catalyst. However, the catalytic cracking obviously inhibited both the coke formation and residue cracking reaction. We investigated the influence of reaction temperature, reaction time and RM concentration on VR conversion. Reaction temperature and time significantly improved the yield of naphtha, diesel and vacuum gas oil; unfortunately, they also increased the gas fraction, which is an undesirable product. Catalyst concentration negligibly affected the VR conversion while vacuum gas oil fraction in product distribution increased with catalyst concentration, indicating that the cracking reaction was suppressed in the presence of catalyst. Through the characterization of fresh and spent catalysts by diverse techniques, it has been determined that the crystalline iron oxide of RM transforms into pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ), an active phase for the hydrocracking reaction, due to presence of sulfur in VR. Our results show that RM is possibly self-activated during the reaction and the pretreatment step can be eliminated. Keywords Red mud Vacuum residue Slurry-phase Hydrocracking 1 Introduction Crude oil still plays a leading role in the global supply of fuels and energy even though there is controversy related to its impact on the environment, including climate change. Vacuum residue (VR) is the heaviest fraction obtained from the vacuum distillation of atmospheric residue (AR). The use of VR as a heavy furnace oil fraction is limited due to its considerable contribution to environmental pollution. These heavy hydrocarbon feedstocks must be converted into more valuable products with lower boiling points. The efficiency of refineries is highly dependent on the availability of processes that convert VR into low-boiling products. VR can be converted into low-boiling fractions through coking, visbreaking, catalytic cracking and hydrocracking processes. Nowadays, many researchers are striving to improve the catalytic hydrocracking process [1–3]. Hydrocracking with a fixed-bed or ebullated-bed reactor has been performed commercially, but there is often a critical problem with catalytic deactivation caused by coking and the deposition of heavy metals, particularly when an increase in the conversion of residue is intended or a heavier feedstock is processed. Slurry-phase residue hydrocracking is a newly developed technique for processing heavy oils [4–6]. It is favorable to achieve high conversion because of the enhancement in the mass-transfer rate, which is beneficial not only to the catalytic reaction, but also for temperature control within the reactor. In today's world, research on the slurry-phase hydrocracking processes is very active. There are now more than 10 such technologies in pilot stages and some of them have already been used in industrialized applications [4]. Catalysts for the slurry-phase hydrocracking of heavy oil have undergone two development phases, i.e., heterogeneous solid powder catalysts and homogeneous dispersed catalysts. Although the homogeneous dispersed catalysts show a better catalytic performance than solid powder catalysts, this does not mean that the solid powder catalysts are not attractive to researchers. There is an ongoing search for a low cost catalyst with good catalytic performance for industrialized applications. Red mud (RM) is a by-product from the manufacturing of alumina by the Bayer process, specifically the solid residue of the caustic leaching of bauxite. The main constituents of RM are iron, titanium and aluminum oxides, with significant silicon, calcium and sodium oxide content. RM has been studied as a hydrogenation catalyst for coal [7,8], biomass [9], oil shale [10], and certain organic compounds [11]. Although RM has less activity than the noble metals and metal oxides, it has a lower price, making it more desirable economically. To our knowledge, there are no reports in the literature on the hydrocracking of VR in the presence of RM. The goal of this research was to assess the utilization of RM as a catalyst for the hydrocracking of VR. Our results demonstrate that the iron oxide in RM is transformed into iron sulfide by hydrodesulfurization of S in feed, and that iron sulfide is an active phase for VR hydrocracking. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The feedstock in the hydrocracking experiments was commercial VR (initial boiling point: 454°C; content: 538°C+residue – 70wt.%, sulfur – 4.4wt.%, nitrogen – 0.48wt.%, C5 asphaltenes – 18.0wt.%, C7 asphaltenes – 10.0wt.%, CCR – 22.9wt.%; and heavy metals: V – 145.1ppm, Ni – 44.5ppm). The RM used in this work was supplied by the KC Corporation (Seoul, South Korea). Catalysts in experiments were used after calcination at 550°C for 2h. For comparison, a sulfide form of RM (SRM) catalyst was prepared under flowing H2S gas mixture (5vol.% H2S and 50vol.% H2 in Ar balance) at 400°C for 2h. 2.2 Hydrocracking of vacuum residue Hydrocracking reactions with or without catalysts were carried out using a 100mL batch type autoclave made of stainless steel and fitted with a stirrer and hydrogen flow system with a 30g feed. In catalytic experiments, 1.2–3.0g of a catalyst was loaded into the reactor. The reactor was pressurized with hydrogen gas to 90bar of pressure. The reactor was heated to 470–500°C under vigorous stirring at a pressure of approximately 150bar. At the end of the reaction time, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature using a water cooler and a fan. The gas products were released to the air. The reactor contents were centrifuged to separate the liquid products. The conversion figures for VR were calculated by balancing the content of desired boiling point products in the following equations: Conversion ( wt . % ) = Products weight of desired boiling point Feed VR weight × 100 Gas conversion ( wt . % ) = [ Input VR weight ] − [ Weight of all of the products ] Feed VR weight × 100 The distribution of each product—naphtha (<150°C), diesel (<350°C), VGO (<560°C), and residue— was measured by GC-SIMDIS (AC Analytical Controls, Agilent 7890). The analysis conditions were based on ASTM D2887 (simulated distillation) and ASTM D5307 methods [12–14]. The remaining product in solid form was extracted with toluene to remove soluble coke deposits, oil, and remaining feed. The toluene-insoluble fraction consisted of coke, catalyst, and inorganic matter. After washing, the spent catalysts were dried in an oven at 120°C for 4h [3]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The composition of RM is determined by an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (FE-SEM-EDX, JEOL, JSM-600F, Japan). The textural properties were measured by means of N2 sorption analysis on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus (USA). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku RAD-3C Diffractometer (Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (l =1.5418Å) at a scan rate of 2° (2θ)/min, operated at 35kV and 20mA. A TA Q50 instrument (USA) using Universal Analysis 2000 under N2/air flow of 60/40mLmin−1 at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 was used to study the TGA of the spent catalyst. The temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) technique was also used extensively to study the coke oxidation rate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reaction parameter analysis We studied the effects of parameters adopted for the slurry phase VR hydrocracking process on the conversion levels of feed, coke formation and product distribution within the following ranges of variability: reaction temperature, 470–500°C; reaction time, 2–4h; catalyst concentration, 4–10wt.%; and hydrogen pressure, 150bar. We studied the effect of temperature on VR conversion, product distribution and coke generation without catalyst and with 1.2g catalyst (4wt.%) at a hydrogen pressure of 150bar with a 2h reaction time. Figs. 1 and 2 show the trend of distillate fraction and coke formation as a function of temperature with and without catalyst. Fig. 1 shows that the yield of coke, gas and light oil (naphtha+diesel) increased as the reaction temperature increased. All of products across the range of temperatures could be separated clearly into liquid and solid phases. However, in the presence of catalyst, the product was obtained as a slurry phase at 470 and 480°C (Fig. 2). When the reaction temperature was increased within the studied range, the most lightweight fractions, gas and naphtha, increased slightly, but were stronger for higher temperatures. In Table 1 , we can see that the absence of the catalyst led to a lighter fraction and more residue conversion than the presence of the catalyst, but the coke yield was 14.07wt.% (at 490°C) and 20.50wt.% (at 500°C), which was significantly greater than the results of 1.13wt.% (at 490°C) and 2.40wt.% (at 500°C) for the presence of the catalyst. Thus, the catalyst obviously inhibited coke formation as well as the residue cracking reaction. Due to the low acidity [15], RM catalyst provides a lower cracking activity so that most reactions involving CC bond cleavage are thermally controlled. The catalyst also provides hydrogen uptake, which controls the evolution of free radicals, thereby inhibiting both condensation and cracking reactions [16]. Fig. 2 shows that the yield of gas and coke increased as the reaction temperature increased. However, the liquid fraction yield (naphtha, diesel and VGO) decreased. The conversion increased due to an increase in gas and coke due to the significant role played by a cracking reaction mechanism at high temperatures in which the feed molecules disappear to successively form VGO, diesel, naphtha, gas, and coke. As the operating temperature rises, the cracking severity increases and more VGO undergoes cracking to lighter fractions at those conditions than during VR cracking, resulting in subsequent cracking of VGO into diesel, naphtha, gas, and coke. The effect of reaction time on VR conversion was studied at different temperatures with 1.2g catalyst at a hydrogen pressure of 150bar. Fig. 3 shows that at 470°C, the product separated clearly into liquid and solid phase after a 4h reaction. Shorter reaction times yielded a slurry phase product. The effect of reaction time on VR conversion is more sensitive to higher temperatures; the solid–liquid separated product was obtained after a 3h reaction at 480°C, or a 2h reaction at 490°C. Increased temperature and reaction time improved the yield of the most valuable fraction, i.e., gasoline, diesel oil and vacuum gas oil, and also increased the production of the gas fraction, which is not so desirable. The effect of the catalyst concentration on VR conversion was studied within the catalyst concentrations of 4–10wt.% (1.2–3.0g) after a 3h reaction at a temperature of 480°C and a pressure of 150bar. The data revealed that VR conversion is constant in practice and reaches about 64–66wt.% over the studied range of catalyst concentrations. Hence, the conversion figure turns out to be slightly dependent only on the catalyst concentration (within the tested range of concentrations). This suggests that the VR cracking reactions are predominantly thermal CC cleavage reactions. The catalyst concentration also had a small effect only on the shares of individual hydrocarbon fractions in the VR hydrocracking products. As seen in Fig. 4 , as the catalyst concentration increased, the yield of coke and light oil (naphtha+diesel) slightly decreased. The reason for this could be that during the slurry phase of heavy oil hydrocracking, the catalyst reacts with the feedstock and the H free radical forms on the surface of the catalyst. The H free radical that forms on the surface of the catalyst could react with the free-radicals of big molecules, thereby restraining the formation of coke during the reaction [17]. However, the increasing catalyst concentration was responsible for a small growth in the production of VGO fractions. Thus, the choice of an appropriate catalyst concentration is very important. 3.2 Characterization of catalyst and spent catalyst The RM surface composition measured by EDX is given in Table 2 ; it is mainly composed of Fe2O3 and Al2O3 together with other oxides including titania. The BET-N2 surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of RM, obtained by nitrogen adsorption, were found to be 21.87m2 g−1, 0.14cm3 g−1, and 25.49nm, respectively. The average particle size of RM was 13.21μm, provided from the KC Corporation. The following minerals were identified by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 5 ): rutile (RU), TiO2; hematite (HE), Fe2O3; goethite (GO), FeO(OH); bayerite (BA), Al(OH)3. The spent catalyst was characterized by collecting the catalyst samples after a 2 or 3h reaction time at different temperatures. Fig. 5 shows X-ray diffractograms for RM, SRM (sulfide form of RM), spent RM and spent SRM after a 2h reaction time at 490°C. The XRD pattern of SRM confirmed the formation of pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ). The progressive decrease in the hematite (Fe2O3) peaks and appearance of pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ) peaks are clearly evident over RM and spent RM. The crystalline phase of spent RM was found to be quite similar to that of SRM and spent SRM, meaning that the crystalline iron oxides were transformed into pyrrhotite during the reaction, which is an active phase for the hydrogenation reaction [11,18,19] due to presence of sulfur in VR. The peak of goethite still present in both of spent RM and spent SRM, whereas SRM does not display such signal. The goethite (FeOOH) is one phase of iron component in RM; during the sulfidation treatment, it was transformed into the sulfide form. No peak of goethite in SRM indicates that almost goethite was completely transformed into the pyrrhotite under sulfidation treatment conditions. The appearance of goethite in spent RM and even in spent SRM, with much lower intensity, could be explained by two ways. First, the transformation of goethite into pyrrhotite during hydrocracking reaction is incompletely. Therefore, a small amount of goethite still presented in spent RM under hydrocracking conditions. Second, pyrrhotite is known as unstable phase in an oxygen-containing atmosphere at high temperature [20]. Therefore, the transformation of goethite could be reversed from pyrrhotite during hydrocracking reaction because of presence of oxygen containing in VR. The transformation of the crystalline phase of RM during the reaction was also apparent based on TGA analysis. Fig. 6a and b shows the TGA and TPO profiles of RM, SRM, spent RM and pure coke after VR hydrocracking at 480°C for 3h. The thermal decomposition behaviors of RM show that the weight loss occurs in the range of 30–200°C (2.12%) due to the evaporation of adsorbed water. The TGA diagram of the SRM sample shows the increase in weight (4.84%) in the range of 200–310°C due to the formation of ferrous sulfate (FeSO4) or hydrated ferrous sulfate. There are two steps for the weight loss; the first step occurs in the range of 310–360°C (3.57%) and the second occurs in the range of 360–630°C (4.01%) due to the release of SO2 during the generation of ferrous sulfate and transformation of hydrated ferrous sulfate to hematite (Fe2O3) [20]. The transformation of Fe(x−1)S x in an oxygen-containing atmosphere may be generalized and can be represented by the reactions shown in Scheme 1 . The TGA diagram of spent RM (Fig. 6a) shows a similar pattern to that of SRM. The TGA diagram of the spent RM sample shows an increase in weight (2.46%) in the range of 220–340°C due to the formation of ferrous sulfate (FeSO4) or hydrated ferrous sulfate, whereas there are no an increase in weight in that range of temperature in case of pure coke. The TPO profile of pure coke (Fig. 6b) shows that there are two peaks centered at 516°C and 550°C correspond the carbon combustion. In the same way, there are two peaks centered at 370°C and 524°C and one shoulder at 570°C were observed at spent RM. The sharp peak centered at 524°C corresponds the burn-off of coke, whereas a peak at 370°C and a shoulder at 570°C which are similar to those of SRM corresponding to the release of SO2 during the transformation of ferrous sulfate to hematite. It can be inferred from the previous data that the active phase for the hydrocracking reaction, pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ), can be transformed from crystalline iron oxide due to presence of sulfur in VR. This processing is illustrated in Scheme 2 . At a high reaction temperature, the sulfur in the feed was decomposed [21] and reacted with iron oxide Fe2O3, which transformed it to the pyrrhotite phase, which serves as the active phase in the hydrocracking of heavy oil. This phenomenon is also apparent based on the change in sulfur concentration in the feed. Before the reaction, 30g of VR contained 1.32g of sulfur, and after 3h reaction at 480°C, the content of sulfur in the liquid fraction was 0.64g, indicating that 0.68g of sulfur was transformed into the solid phase and gas phase. Sulfur in the feed should be transferred to the volatile compounds of sulfur in the gas phase and the pyrrhotite phase in the catalyst or should remain in the un-reactive phase. Bhattacharyya at al. [22] also found that the iron oxide in the presence of alumina, particularly in bauxite, quickly converts into active iron sulfide without the need for presenting excess sulfur to the catalyst in the presence of heavy hydrocarbon feed and hydrogen at high temperature as required for other SHC catalyst before addition to the reaction zone. In Matsumuraa's work [3], the natural limonite was used as catalyst for hydrocracking of Brazilian Marlim vacuum residue. Because the main component of limonite is goethite (FeOOH) which has no practical cracking activity as well as hydrogenation activity, the sulfur powder was added to promote formation of pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ) by reaction of Fe and S during heating. However, in our study, we investigated that RM could be used as catalyst for hydrocracking of vacuum residue and RM could be self-activated due to high content of sulfur in vacuum residue (sulfur – 4.4wt.%). The TGA diagrams of spent RM at different reaction temperatures (Fig. 7 ) show the different weight losses in the range of 400–600°C. The weight loss corresponding to the burning of coke deposits increased as reaction temperature increased. This finding indicates that coking occurred strongly at a higher reaction temperature. The cracking of VR is chiefly a thermal process, and the coking potential of VR is strongly dependent on temperature. When the temperature is higher, the cracking reaction is fiercer, and the yield of coke is higher. Fig. 8 shows the TGA profiles of spent RM with different catalyst amounts after a 3h reaction at 480°C. The different weight losses in the range of 400–600°C, corresponding to the burning of coke deposits, correspond to the trend of coke formation as a function of catalyst concentration. The increase in the catalyst concentration led to the much lower weight loss, suggesting that a much smaller amount of coke was generated. 4 Conclusions Based on the research on slurry-phase hydrocracking of VR, the RM employed in the hydrocracking tests was found to be a moderately active VR cracking catalyst. The results can be summarized as follows: (1) Without RM, thermal cracking occurred, producing a lighter fraction and higher conversion than in the presence of catalyst. However, the catalytic cracking obviously inhibited both the coke formation and residue cracking reaction. (2) Research on the effects of processing parameters on VR hydrocracking revealed that the catalyst concentration had little effect on VR hydrocracking; the ratio between the diesel and VGO fraction decreased as the amount of catalyst increased. The conversion of the feedstock to distillate is thermally controlled; VR hydrocracking was strongly affected by reaction temperature and reaction time. Increased temperature and reaction time improved the yield of the most valuable fraction, i.e., naphtha, diesel oil and vacuum gas oil, and also increased the production of the gas fraction, which is not a desirable product. (3) During the reaction, the crystalline iron oxides are transformed into pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ), which is the active phase for the hydrocracking reaction, due to presence of sulfur in VR. coredata.dc:description: In this study, red mud (RM) was used as a catalyst in slurry-phase hydrocracking of vacuum residue (VR) in batch system. Without RM, thermal cracking occurred and a lighter fraction and higher conversion was achieved than in the presence of catalyst. However, the catalytic cracking obviously inhibited both the coke formation and residue cracking reaction. We investigated the influence of reaction temperature, reaction time and RM concentration on VR conversion. Reaction temperature and time significantly improved the yield of naphtha, diesel and vacuum gas oil; unfortunately, they also increased the gas fraction, which is an undesirable product. Catalyst concentration negligibly affected the VR conversion while vacuum gas oil fraction in product distribution increased with catalyst concentration, indicating that the cracking reaction was suppressed in the presence of catalyst. Through the characterization of fresh and spent catalysts by diverse techniques, it has been determined that the crystalline iron oxide of RM transforms into pyrrhotite (Fe(x−1)S x ), an active phase for the hydrocracking reaction, due to presence of sulfur in VR. Our results show that RM is possibly self-activated during the reaction and the pretreatment step can be eliminated.
coredata.dc:title: Slurry-phase hydrocracking of vacuum residue with a disposable red mud catalyst
